title: Whales & Dolphins
description: Identify species of whales and dolphins from descriptions

questions.question: Which marine mammal is the largest animal ever known to have lived on Earth, reaching lengths of up to 100 feet and weighing as much as 200 tons?
Which whale is known for its long, complex songs that can travel thousands of miles through the ocean and for its spectacular breaching behavior?
Which toothed whale has the largest brain of any animal and was famously featured in Herman Melville's novel 'Moby-Dick'?
Which small, white whale is sometimes called the 'canary of the sea' because of its wide range of vocalizations including clicks, whistles, and chirps?
Which Arctic whale has a long, spiral tusk that can grow up to 10 feet, earning it the nickname 'unicorn of the sea'?
Which is the fastest dolphin species, capable of swimming at speeds up to 20 miles per hour, and is commonly seen riding the bow waves of boats?
Which dolphin is actually the largest member of the oceanic dolphin family, known for its black-and-white coloring and hunting in coordinated pods?
Which whale is known for its extremely long migrations, traveling up to 12,000 miles round trip between Arctic feeding grounds and Mexican breeding lagoons?
Which dolphin is famous for its acrobatic spinning leaps, rotating up to seven times on a single jump out of the water?
Which whale has a distinctive pink coloration and lives exclusively in freshwater rivers of South America, including the Amazon?
Which baleen whale is the second-largest animal on Earth, identifiable by its asymmetrical coloring â€” dark on the left jaw and white on the right?
Which Arctic whale can live over 200 years, making it one of the longest-lived mammals, and has an extremely thick skull used to break through sea ice?
Which dolphin species is the most commonly seen in aquariums and marine parks, known for its curved mouth that gives it a permanent 'smile'?
Which small porpoise is the most endangered cetacean in the world, with fewer than 10 individuals remaining in Mexico's Gulf of California?
Which large whale was hunted nearly to extinction for the oil in its head cavity, which was used for lamp fuel and lubricants in the 18th and 19th centuries?
